_prev_prog_2.PC_OtherType: Administrative control limit for each tank fill capacity set to 88% of total capicity.
_prev_prog_2.MD_OtherType: Remote tank monitoring via cellular antenna
_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: Tanks, piping, supports, valves and safety devices
_prev_prog_2.Description:
3.0 PROGRAM 2 PREVENTION PROGRAM

Program 2 eligibility requirements are necessary for facilities that do not meet the eligibility

requirements of either Program 1 or Program 3. There are seven elements in the Program 2

prevention program, which is set forth in the 40 CFR Part 68 regulations at Subpart C.



3.1 Safety Information (? 68.48)

GDI-P&IP shall compile and maintain the up-to-date safety information related to the regulated

substances, processes, and equipment.

? Safety Data Sheets (SDS) that meet the requirements of 29 CFR 1910.1200(g) are

available in Appendix B and will be kept current.

? The maximum fill setting in each tank is limited to 88 percent, controlling the maximum

propylene storage to 3,502 gallons of liquid contained within tanks. Piping associated with

the supply system contain a negligible amount of gas phase propylene. At 4.28 lbs./gal for

propylene at 20?C the total maximum liquid storage capacity is 14,989 pounds.

? Materials of construction for the propylene system include steel tanks, steel and/or Type

K piping, threaded fittings and/or soldered with 15% solder, valves, regulators and

flashback arrestors. Full details of system construction are included in piping and

instrumentation diagrams (P&IDs) located in Figures 5A/5B.

? The following design codes and standards were employed in the construction of the

propylene system: NFPA-58, NFPA-30, NFPA-51, OSHA 29 CFR 1910.110 and

Compressed Gas Association.

Appropriate engineering controls are required during Spray operations to ensure adequate

ventilation is provided to keep worker exposure below applicable limits for fumes, dusts, gases,

and other by-products. Fumes or gases should not be breathed, short-term overexposure to

fumes may cause dizziness, nausea, and dryness or irritation of the nose, throat, and eyes, or

may cause other similar discomfort. Use an explosion-proof local exhaust system and general

ventilation that is adequate to meet exposure standards. Use of protected explosion proof

equipment and lighting is required in the Spray room.

Suitable work gloves should be worn when handling containers and welding gloves are required

for welding/heating parts. Care should be taken to keep gloves free of oil and grease, gloves with

oil and grease shall not be used for the Spray process.

Eye protection must be worn at all times and will consist of safety glasses with side shields or

goggles when transfilling or breaking transfer connections. During Spray operations a face shield

is required. Safety boots are required onsite, the use of flame resistant anti-static safety clothing

is recommended.

Respiratory protection is required when workplace conditions warrant respirator use. Respiratory

protection program is required that meets OSHA 29 CFR 1910.134. Use an air-supplied or airpurifying

cartridge if the action level is exceeded and ensure the respirator has the appropriate

protection factor for the exposure level. If cartridge type respirators are used, the cartridge must

be appropriate for the chemical exposure present. For emergencies or instances with unknown

exposure levels, use a self-contained breathing apparatus (SCBA).

The exposure to liquid propylene may cause frostbite, appropriate thermal hazard protection such

as cold insulating gloves are required when transfilling or breaking transfer connections.



3.2 Hazard Review (? 68.50)

GDI-P&IP shall conduct a review of the hazards associated with the regulated substances,

process, and procedures. GDI-P&IP will document the results of the review and ensure that

problems identified are resolved in a timely manner. The review shall be updated at a minimum

of once every five years. GDI-P&IP shall also conduct additional reviews whenever a major

change in the process occurs and confirm issues identified in the review are resolved before

startup of the changed process.

GDI-P&IP use checklists developed by persons knowledgeable about the process and equipment

as a guide to conducting the review, checklists are located in Appendix C. For processes designed

to meet industry standards or Federal or state design rules, the hazard review shall, by inspecting

equipment to determine whether the process is designed, fabricated, and operated in accordance

with the applicable standards or rules.

The review shall be updated at a minimum of once every five years. GDI-P&IP shall also conduct

reviews whenever a major change in the process occurs and confirm issues identified in the

review are resolved before startup of the changed process. Completed hazard review checklist

are located in Appendix E.



3.3 Operating Procedures (? 68.52)

These procedures are the guide for informing employees how to work safely every day, giving

everyone a quick source of information that can prevent or mitigate the effects of an accident, and

providing workers and management with a standard against which to assess performance.

Operating procedures are provided in Appendix D and will be readily accessible to employees

who operate or maintain the system.

The operating procedures will be reviewed as often as necessary to assure that they reflect

current operating practice, including changes that result from changes in process chemicals,

technology, and equipment, and changes to stationary sources. GDI-P&IP will certify annually

that these operating procedures are current and accurate (Appendix D).

GDI-P&IP has developed and implemented safe work practices to provide for the control of

hazards during operations such as lockout/tagout; start up; shut down; temporary operations;

emergency shut down; start up following major change or emergency; consequences of deviation;

process equipment inspections; and control over entrance into a stationary source by

maintenance, contractor, or other support personnel. These safe work practices are applied to

employees and contractor employees.



3.4 Training (? 68.54)

Training for employees that are involved with operating the system will be completed as outlined

in Appendix D. The training will be completed by personnel competent with the Spray process

and propylene supply system. In addition, the training will include a review of the operating

procedures with an emphasis on specific safety and health hazards, emergency operations

including shutdown, and safe work practices applicable to the employee's job tasks. Additional

hands on training will be provided to personnel for specialized tasks or when processes change.

For employees responsible for maintaining the system, training will include operating procedures

associated with maintenance of the equipment mechanical integrity.

Refresher Training

Refresher training shall be provided at least every year, and more often if necessary, to each

employee involved in operating the system to assure that employees understand and adhere to

the operating procedures provided in Appendix D. The content of the refresher training will be

similar to the information provided during initial training. Copies of training records are located in

Appendix E.



3.4.1 Change of Process or Materials Training

Training will be required for employees involved with operating the system when it is determined

that a process, procedure, or material has changed that would affect the operation of equipment

or storage.



3.4.2 Training Documentation

GDI-P&IP shall document that each employee involved in operating or maintaining the system

has received and understood the training described above. Employee training records are

maintained in the facility?s training database and will document:

? Date of most recent review/revision of training programs.

? Type of training provided.

? Type of competency test used.

Copies of the most recent training procedures are located in Appendix E.



3.5 Maintenance (? 68.56)

Preventive maintenance, inspection, and testing of equipment is critical to safe operations.

Waiting for equipment to fail often means waiting for an accident that could harm people and the

environment.

GDI-P&IP maintains the integrity of the propylene system by completing maintenance activities

as specified in documents provided by the manufacturer of the components of the system.

Specifically, the following manufacturer's maintenance programs are used on specific

components of the system:

? Tanks

? Piping

? Supports

? Valves

? Safety devices

? Detection/alarm system

? Supply

The activities include inspection and testing of pressure vessels, emergency shutdown, controls,

pumps, and other equipment associated with operating the system.

Inspection and testing procedures have been developed by that follow recognized and generally

accepted good engineering practices. The frequency of inspections and tests of process

equipment will be consistent with applicable manufacturers? recommendations, industry

standards or codes, good engineering practices and prior operating experience.

Employees responsible for the on-going integrity of process equipment on the system will be

trained in an overview of the process. Training will include a review of the hazards associated

with as well as operating procedures associated with maintaining the equipment integrity.

GDI-P&IP has developed a checklist to document each inspection and test that is required to be

completed on the system. The checklist located in Appendix F identifies the following information:

? date of the inspection or test;

? name of the person who performed the inspection or test;

? serial number or other identifier of the equipment on which the inspection or test was

performed;

? description of the inspection or test performed; and

? results of the inspection or test.

When deficiencies are identified during inspections, GDI-P&IP will correct the problem to return

the system to acceptable parameter limits specified in the process safety information. Corrections

will occur before further use or in a safe and timely manner, when necessary means are taken to

assure safe operation.

GDI-P&IP has constructed the system and assured that the equipment, as it is fabricated, is

suitable for the process application. Appropriate checks and inspections are performed to assure

that equipment is installed properly and consistent with design specifications and the

manufacturer's instructions. GDI-P&IP assures that the maintenance materials, spare parts and

equipment are suitable for the system by completing the pre-startup safety review.

Pre Startup Review

A pre-startup safety review will be completed on the system prior to initial startup or when a

modification is significant enough to require a change in the process safety information. The prestart-

up safety review will confirm the following information prior to the introduction of system:

? Equipment is constructed in accordance with design specifications;

? Safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are in place and are

adequate;

? For new stationary sources, a process hazard analysis has been performed and

recommendations have been resolved or implemented before startup; and

? Training of each employee involved in operating the process has been completed.

Operating procedures have been developed for initial startup and startup following an emergency

shutdown.



3.6 Compliance Audits (? 68.58)

The Risk Management program should be reviewed periodically to ensure that employees and

contractors are implementing the audits properly. A compliance audit is a way to evaluate and

measure the effectiveness of your risk management program. In accordance with 40 CFR 68.58,

GDI-P&IP will evaluate compliance with this Plan at least once every three years to verify that the

procedures and practices developed are adequate and being followed. The compliance audit has

been developed to ensure that employees and contractors are implementing the risk management

program properly. The audit will be conducted by a person knowledgeable with the covered

process. The audit?s findings will be reported on the checklist provided in Appendix G and written

reports of the findings and corresponding corrective actions taken will be maintained for five years.

Completed checklist are located in Appendix E.



3.7 Incident Investigation (? 68.60)

Incidents can provide valuable information about site hazards and the steps you need to take to

prevent accidental releases. Often, the immediate cause of an incident is the result of a series of

other problems that need to be addressed to prevent recurrences.

GDI-P&IP will investigate each incident which resulted in, or could have reasonably resulted in, a

catastrophic release, in accordance with 40 CFR 68.60. An incident investigation will be initiated

as soon as possible, but no later than 48 hours after the incident occurred. GDI-P&IP will quickly

address and resolve the investigation findings and recommendations, and resolutions and

corrective actions will be documented and maintained for five years.

An Incident Report is used by GDI-P&IP to document, address, and resolve the findings of the

investigation. The report includes the following information:

? Date of incident;

? Date of investigation;

? Detailed description of the incident;

? List factors that contributed to the incident; and,

? Include recommendations resulting from the investigation.

The Incident Report also includes fields for documenting resolutions and corrective actions. Upon

completion, the report will be reviewed with affected personnel whose job tasks are relevant to

the incident findings including contract employees, where applicable. Appendix H contains the

Environmental & Safety Management Program effective January 01, 2020.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This Risk Management Plan (RMP) is established for Gardner Denver Petroleum & Industrial

Pumps (GDI-P&IP) Aledo facility. The RMP is developed in accordance with the United States

Environmental Protection Agency's (USEPA) Chemical Accident Prevention regulations 40 CFR

Part 68 with Program 2 requirements for facilities were flammable endpoint for a worst-case

release assessment exceeds the distance to public receptors. The purpose of this RMP document

is to assist with the prevention of accidental releases of flammable substances that can cause

harm to the public, facility employees and the environment.

The GDI-P&IP Aledo facility stores Liquefied Petroleum Gas (propylene, CAS No.115-07-1) for

use in pump plunger manufacturing operations exceeding Table 3: ?68.130 - List of Regulated

Flammable Substances and Threshold Quantities for Accidental Release Prevention of 10,000

pounds. The facility maintains two 1,990-gallon tanks for a total potential capacity of 3,980 gallons

(17,034 pounds). The propylene system is designed, installed, and maintained in accordance with

federal, state, and local laws.

Risk is defined by the combination of the probability or likelihood that the process will experience

an event and the consequences, impact, or severity of the event. Each process assumes some

element of risk, however, when risk management techniques are applied to monitor and track

events with the potential to impact operations, the overall risk can be minimized at the facility.

This facility complies with National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) requirements for LP-Gas

storage, and will adhere to applicable federal, state, and local laws. In the event of an emergency,

it is our policy to notify the Fire Department and request assistance in respond to an emergency.

The worst-case scenario evaluated is failure of the storage tank system when filled to the greatest

amount allowed (88% at 20?C), resulting in a vapor cloud explosion. The resulting dista

nce to the

endpoint extends offsite, and public receptors are within the distance to the endpoint. The

alternative release scenario analyzed is a break in a 0.25-inch diameter hose, leading to a 240-

minute release inside the Spray Room and subsequent vapor cloud explosion. The resulting

distance to the endpoint extends offsite, and public receptors are within the distance to the

endpoint.

The facility has no reported accidents involving propylene that caused deaths, injuries, property

or environmental damage, evacuations, or required sheltering in place orders.

The system is equipped with safety measures to prevent accidental release and equipment to

detect a release. In the event of an emergency involving the propylene system, it is policy to notify

the Fire Department and request assistance responding to the emergency. We will coordinate our

response plan with the fire department and have the fire department inspect the propylene system

and conducted joint exercises.
